reviews.Comments: I ended up working at SAP after getting rejected from this opportunity and I wouldn't recommend it. I was only paid 30$/hr. There was a big layoff in the UX design team shortly before I joined, which was quite demoralizing as I was really excited about the prospect of maybe returning full-time. However, the return offer rate is also very low. Overall, pretty dissatisfied with my experience.

interviewDetails.1767605139273:
Only 1 round of interviews, recruiter did not specify the format of the interview process. This was my first UX design interview so I wasn't sure what to expect, and I was caught off guard when they asked me to share my screen and present a project to them. I shared my portfolio website and walked them through the project. After I realized that the better candidates have prepared a slide deck walking them through the work. I wish that this was communicated early on in the process.

Otherwise I was asked the standard behavioral questions of 
1. Tell me about yourself
2. Why do you want to work at SAP?
3. What's your greatest strength?
4. What's your greatest weakness?

reviews.Comments: Tesla interviews are hard to prep for because questions vary a lot and often dont match the job description. The JD is for the org, not the team, so you might get behavioral, LeetCode, system design, or API questions. Best prep is strong DSA fundamentals with LeetCode (Blind 75 is enough) and knowing your resume well. Communication matters a lot. Explain clearly, keep it conversational, and check if the interviewer is following. If there are multiple rounds with the same team, pay attention to what they share and bring it up later to show you care and listen

reviews.Comments: I was a direct consider- no apply/no OA.

interviewDetails.1766014783887: 15 min behavioral, 40 min coding, 5 min questions. Tested on Amazon LPs, coding question was related to checking whether two lists of book versions were the same (don't remember exact constraints). For behavioral, be sure to use STAR method & know Amazon LPs. Don't repeat a scenario. For coding, take your time and clarify everything with your interviewer. Make sure they know your thought process! I did not know specific syntaxes at times, but the interviewer knew what I tried to do and allowed me to assume some certain functions' syntax. Difficulty- easy.
interviewDetails.1766014812933:
The Loop- essentially 3 Phone interviews back-to-back-to-back. 15 minute behavioral, 45 minute coding for each round, with 15 minute breaks in between. Once again, tested on Amazon LPs, coding was slightly harder, and included a low level system design which essentially has no constraints- its all up to you! This one will be draining (was for me atleast) so be sure to pace yourself.

Once again, don't reuse your stories! All interviewers from Final + Phone come together to talk about your responses, so make sure no two interviewers have the same story.

reviews.Comments: Lower pay than SWE intern, but you do get the same $2k USD relocation package.

interviewDetails.1764275559412:

interviewDetails.1764275610071:
Final was 2 1hr interviews back to back. I believe there's no clear guidance on what the rounds can be, up to interviewer

Round 1 - Tech/Behavioral
30mins behavioral/light tech trivia, 30 mins coding
First asked about normal LPs, then got asked extremely simple SQL questions (what is a foreign key, what are all 3 type of joins)
Asked valid palindrome, then 3 simple SQL questions (joins, fix this query, use a group by)

Round 2 - Behav/Light System Design
Generic LPs, then got a deep resume review/light system design. He probed into one of my past internships and asked how I would design some variation of a technology I had used, and how I would optimize it (Sharding, scaling, etc)

reviews.InterviewProcess:

reviews.InterviewInformation:
"Tell me about a time where you had to make a quick decision with little data" Forgot the second question but both questions were related to Customer Obsession, Ownership, Insist on highest standards, think big, bias for action, and dive deep. 

1 leetcode easy question where you had to preprocess an array and add its contents onto a heap and pop. Optimal solution could be solved with quick select but interviewer wanted only the heap solution. I was told straight up by the interviewer that it is ok to code out a brute force solution, and that you'd get hints towards optimizing it if you can't come up with the optimal solution right off the bat. 

If anything, focus more on your leadership principles as they seem to care about that more than the technical. Prepare stories for each leadership principle in the STAR format. 

I originally had this offer for Summer 2025, but wanted to defer to Fall. Amazon does not allow this so I had to decline the offer and email them that I was interested in being reconsidered for Fall instead. 1 week later got the offer for Fall 2025, didn't need to reinterview. Make sure you email them to indicate your interest for Fall instead of Summer, and decline the offer, they will put you on a waitlist and give you an offer once a spot opens. I know several other people who managed to get their offers deferred to Fall.
reviews.Comments: 2k USD/month housing

- Luckily, I got 2Sum and ordered 2Sum as follow up. Was able to breeze through it and get to the Q&A section.

The interviewer was somewhat impersonal and stonic. It was pretty hard to read how well the interview was going.

Also, I applied with a referral from another intern. Not sure how much that would influence the process, but it doesn't seem like you'd have to pass the OA to get an interview!!!

TC: $8,061/month + $2,000USD/month for relocation stipend (make sure to enter a far enough address to get this).

reviews.InterviewInformation:
1) Recruiter email: Was first reached out to via email by a recruiter, after I received a referral from another Jr. SDE. 
 - Got asked 13 questions about myself, my school, my experience with tech and some other personality questions. 

Received a response to schedule a phone interview after 5 days.

2) Phone Interview: 

15 minute behavioural based on Amazon LPs. 
- Basic tell me about yourself
- Specific question on if I had previous experience with AWS. 
- General LP questions, mostly on LP's that they'd expect for interns (Dive deep, Invent and Simplify)

45 minute LC style interview
- LC easy, using a set and and array
- Heavy emphasis on "good" code (structured, easy to read, proper naming conventions)
- Talked through a solution first, then got to go-ahead to implement.
- Was asked time complexity only 

Interviewer was extremely nice, we talked for 20~ minutes since I finished the LC part in 10 mins. 

Received an email for next steps after 1 day.

3) Loop interview 

3 interviews in a row, with shorter time for the LC section. 15 minute break in-between. One of the interviewers is a "bar raiser", but you aren't told who. This person has veto power on your hiring decision. 

15 minute behavioural based on LPs
- Covered almost all relevant LP's
- Was specifically pushed back on story, and asked to say a different one.
- Bar raiser (found out in hindsight) asked much trickier questions 
- Heavy emphasis on LP's that apply to interns 


30 minute LC
- 1 Easy, designing question 
- 2 Mediums, one simulation question, one sorting question

Received an offer after 2 days.
reviews.Comments:
Jr. SDE is a lot harder of an interview process since they plan to keep you long term. Bar raiser interview was the hardest (think I know who it was in hindsight). Being passionate about what you're talking about helps a LOT. 

Behavioural are taken very seriously. Make sure to know every LP, and have multiple stories you can use.

reviews.InterviewInformation: All the lc were around the easy to easy-medium range. Got asked a bunch of leadership principle questions during all rounds too.
reviews.Comments: Prep answers to leadership principle questions beforehand (ideally have multiple for each). Try to be comfortable solving easier lc mediums < 20mins. Also wouldn't focus on DP or advanced algos.

Amazon is salaried monthly, so I was offered $8,061. Total compensation also includes $2k USD/month relocation stipend. 

For prepping the technical stuff, I would recommend doing the questions on the Neetcode 150 list. 

Amazon is 3 days in office (until January 2025).

Received RO about 3 weeks after Internship ended. TC: 113.8k Base + 42.9k/34k Bonus + 111k stock over 4 years (5/15/40/40)

Not sure what happened to my team, but I think there was a big reorg happening and I was moved to another team. They will assign you to a team based on their business needs.

interviewDetails.1765147273393: Standard CodeSignal GCA, 70 min - can be researched online since the format and assortment of questions is the same throughout.
interviewDetails.1765147394688:
Interview is split into 2 parts. 

Behavioral - group interview. My advice is to LEAD! You need to take initiative, offer to share your screen, create the google doc for planning, ask for opinions or suggestions, acknowledge them, etc. You have to stand out, can't be quiet IMO

Technical - LC easy & System design. Not too in depth (won't ask you about cache or load balancing etc but good to have), might ask a lot about the schema you chose + tech stack. 

Overall, don't stress it too much, being able to explain your thought process to the interviewer, even if you can't code out part of the solution, helps a lot! :)

reviews.Comments: Making it to the last round does not guarantee anything. They will review your resume, skills and past OA and interview after you completed everything even the reference check.

interviewDetails.1758215259757: Standard OA, 3 algorithm questions, an IQ test and a behavioral test
interviewDetails.1758215301551: OOP pair programming. Pretty simple, and they want us to use AI (strongly encouraged). You have to show them how good you are at using AI as ur peer
interviewDetails.1758215333673: Asked about my previous experience, and a few questions focus on Shopify's key values. My interviewer looks very positive; they also asked me about my preferred role and office location at the end. I got my reference check done but still end up getting rejected

reviews.InterviewProcess: OA -> Technical Interview (Pair Programming) -> Life Story
reviews.InterviewInformation:
The OA appears to have been RNG I had a fairly easy problem but I know others who had more difficult problems.

The Technical Interview was pretty calm. I enjoyed how it was more about working with your interviewer to solve the problem rather than just getting the right answer. They also allowed us to use AI for the interview! For this round I wasnt directly tested on data structures and algorithms, so Id focus more on knowing how the programming language of your choice works.

The Life Story Interview felt like a unique behavioural interview to me. Id recommend reading all the information they send over and show your growth and passion in your responses. Also treat it like a conversation dont memorize points and share them.
reviews.Comments: * Salary excludes a $1000 monthly allowance.

reviews.InterviewInformation:
life story:
- was asked about a question from the portal. ie) how did you feel reading the letter from toby?
- why software engineering, talk about your background and experiences and what led you to pursue swe

reviews.InterviewProcess: 1 60 minute recruiter screen, 90 minute technical interview
reviews.InterviewInformation: Recruiter call asks you about your projects, information from your candidate portal, mainly to see if you fit the company culture. 90 minute technical where the first 40 minutes are about a personal project you talk about (demo it if you can), and a 50 minute OOP-style problem, where they're just trying to see if you can 1. Code 2. keep in mind best practices while being under a time crunch. LC will be useless for this round, just make sure you can code + test in a specific language proficiently and you will pass :)
reviews.Comments: Keep in mind that Shopify has changed the order of interviews, this was from Fall 2024 when the process was slightly different. Overall an easy process, practice more being a kind-to-work-with person rather than being a LC master.

reviews.InterviewInformation: OA was a full-stack project. Recruiter "life story" was just telling my life story and how I got to where I was. Technical interview was some pair programming on a series of questions that got harder and harder

interviewDetails.1765482548429: 2 questions, 1 easy, 1 med-hard question. Topics vary widely.
interviewDetails.1765483519140: Back to back final rounds with 2 different engineering managers. Both had a mix of behavioral, resume grilling, and a leetcode style technical question. Topics vary widely again here.

reviews.Comments: Besides the base salary, there are pretty cool benefits (like housing, prime card for discounts, and other allowances)

interviewDetails.1764104223386: There was one lc style question (precisely sliding window). It was not lc tagged though. It was easy to implement, but of course it had to be optimal. 9/10 experience. For advice, I would just say that its the explore program, so theres nothing too hard here.
interviewDetails.1764104370390: It was split in two halves. The first part was a random behavioural where I had to talk about college and projects on my resume (with follow ups). The second part was tagged technical excellence so was a more technical behavioural (i was asked questions to see how I would act in technical/professional situations). Just be yourself here :)

reviews.Comments: Recruiter was nice :)

interviewDetails.1763321455146:
Easiest OA I've ever seen. Hackerrank - write a simple regexp to filter out certain words from a list.

Called for interview in October, which I declined as I had already accepted another offer by then.

behaviourals for both finals. typical resume questions, how you work in a team, etc.

interviewDetails.1760034387284: easy question, not on leetcode. i dont remember

2 HackerRank problems. Both were LeetCode medium-level problems.
First one was a HashMap problem.
The second one was greedy.

Hashmap one was on the easier side, the greedy one was on the harder side of medium.
interviewDetails.1759953359184:
Two 45-minute rounds with a 15-minute break in between.
Mix of behavioural + resume + technical questions. One coding problem per interview.

Resume questions went over past experiences.
About 3 behavioural questions per interview, one question was "If your teammate approached a problem differently from you, how would you approach them about your solution?".

You spend roughly 15 minutes on behavioural and given 30 for the coding portion.

Coding Problems:
1) Reverse a linked list
2) Variation of maximum product subarray

reviews.InterviewProcess: 2 x 45 min back to back interviews
reviews.InterviewInformation:
Both interviews had behavioural + technical
Technical can be LC or LLD or sys design
Difficulty random, avg med

reviews.InterviewProcess: Straight to final, 2 x 45 min interviews back to back
reviews.InterviewInformation:
1. Best Time to Buy and Sell Stock
2. Wildcard Matching
reviews.Comments:
- Final difficulty is RNG. Usually easy-med
- You may get 2 LC easies or sys design, or even a LC hard
- I suggest studying Neetcode 150 over tagged questions
- Prepare for behaviourals as well and resume grill
Timing is everything because Hubspot does reach headcount fast. I didnt do my OA on time, so that stretched out my timeline and made decisions stiffer since a lot of offers had already been put out.

interviewDetails.1764105260304: It was an ICA on codesignal (proctoring was optional), so was basically a four step object oriented programming question. The first two were trivial and the third was low-key implementation heavy and the fourth was to be solved optimally. Hubspot is low-key rng, so some people that got 480/600 moved on to the next stage and some 580s were rejected.
interviewDetails.1764105356100: It was brief. Ten minutes, four questions, your regular behavioural. Just prep like you prep for behaviorals.
interviewDetails.1764105371624: Since I went the front end route, I got JavaScript trivia. It was three questions with follow-ups. I would suggest studying object oriented principles in JavaScript and watching namastejs YouTube playlists. My interviewer was pretty nice, so it was a cool session. (It was a coding technical round on coderpad)
interviewDetails.1764105454007: The second technical round is also rng, so I got a http get request problem. I was to perform arithmetic operations on same data in a json. Pretty trivial for the first part. Every question after required a recursive solution. My interviewer was pretty non-verbal, so I knew I was cooked.

reviews.Comments:
The interview process has changed since when I did my process. For example, they now give candidates a CodeSignal ICF instead of the API challenge. 

I would recommend being in office if you are grinding for a RO. The interns in office with me were really fun to work/explore the city with, and we had a lot of good times. You are able to in-person network with HubSpotters also in office, and the free food on Wednesday/Thursday lunches isn't half bad.

interviewDetails.1763170512328: API Challenge. Had to make GET/POST functionalities.
interviewDetails.1763170633151:
Extremely important. The recruiter is looking to see if you are a good fit for HubSpot's culture and have taken the necessary steps in researching the company thoroughly. 

Lots of people get rejected here because they overlook its importance.
interviewDetails.1763170635333:
First Interview - Coding (60 min): LC easy problem. Spend some time asking clarifying questions before diving into the code. Wrapped it up with 25 min to spare so just ended up chatting with the interviewer about life in Cambridge as he was in office.

Second Interview - JavaScript (60 min): Several parts that test core JS concepts. javascript.info is very helpful for this.

reviews.InterviewInformation: Basic behavioral for phone screen. Javascript + leetcode for frontend role, system design + leetcode for backend role. Generally some additional behavioral questions in technical round as well.

First interview was recruiter phone screen. Talked about HEART values, why you want to join HubSpot. Very chill and nice recruiter.

Second interview was a 45 min leetcode interview. I would rate the problem as LC easy; however, they judge very carefully on your thought process - defining the problem, edgecases etc. Personally I finished the LC part in 10-15 minutes and rest of the interview was chatting with the interviewer.

Lastly, there was a 45 min system design interview (Design Netflix). This was a very enjoyable process. I had to clear the fundamentals, i.e. database and API design, before the deep dives.The interviewer gave me hints when I was stuck and asked a ton of followup questions on my design. I learned some stuff I've never thought about during this interview, such as cost optimization and observability.
reviews.Comments: Got my offer exactly a week after the final system design interview. Overall, the recruiting process was quite pleasant and recruiter was prompt all the way through.

reviews.InterviewProcess: OA -> Phone -> 2 x 1 hour finals back to back

- LC easy difficulty, one question
- Prepare for follow-ups

2nd final (javascript)

- vanilla JS questions
- javascript.info first section is useful

- the behaviourals are similar to recruiter phone

reviews.InterviewInformation:
The OA is random but questions are generally easy. I got 93% in the OA and got reached out.

Questions for the interview is complete team-dependent. The team I interviewed for deals with the backend of CoD marketplace.

- Python
    - List vs. Tuple
    - List vs. Set
    - Something about GIL and multithreading in Python
- Web Dev
    - Status codes
    - HTTP methods
    - GET vs. POST data
    - How would you prevent SQL Injection and XSS attack
- Coding question about displaying a N x N multiplication table 
- Other
    - Asked if I knew C++
    - Asked if I knew Linux
    - Asked if I knew database indexing
    - TCP vs. UDP
OA with 3 questions (2 lc + 1 fixing existing code), interview had lots of trivia/coding questions related to the team itself
Verbal quiz about python, linux, OS, and Docker. Questions about projects and experiences.

reviews.Comments: Received interview via recruiter reachout on LinkedIn on Sept of 2024, got official interview email on January.

interviewDetails.1744793046944: Just a casual chat with an engineer from the team about my resume, went pretty deep into asking about the specific technical aspects of my work experience. Also got asked about my personal projects (InternDB) and got to talk about my reason for building the project.
interviewDetails.1744793063394: Had an OOD question where I implemented a call class, where I had to implement functions to establish a two-way communication between users, as well as disconnecting the call, removing both users from the call, and error handling.

reviews.Comments: Received interview via recruiter reachout on LinkedIn on Sept of 2024, got official interview email on January. Work is 3 days in the office and 2 days remote, with $650 USD/week on housing costs as well as other intern benefits. Interview process as well as hearing back is very very slow. I got reached out on LinkedIn for an interview back in Sept 23, 2024 and didn't get an official interview invite until January of 2025, and I got my offer 3 months after in April.

interviewDetails.1744703061905: First round was a LeetCode-style round, where I got asked a String Decoding question similar to leetcode 394. I was tasked to decode a given string, given the methodologies given in the question, and then talked a bit about my background and resume.
interviewDetails.1744703099717: Second round was with a team member who asked me a lot of questions about my resume as well as typical "tell me about a time" questions. We had a chat about my interviewer's background as well as mine, nothing out of the ordinary from a standard behavioural round.
interviewDetails.1744703116014: Last round was another technical round (OOD and not leetcode) with another team member, where I was tasked to fetch data from a sample API and retrieve certain data from it. They gave me a site where it listed all the HTTP methods I was able to make and the JSON data that it returned, and I just had to filter certain data and return it to the user. After implementing everything, I got asked a follow-up, where I was asked how I would change my code if I were pushing this to production, where I added error handling and messages.

reviews.InterviewInformation:
Phone screen:
- This was fairly simple and straight forward.
- The recruiter just asked questions on resume, and vibe you out. The questions centred on what was on the resume as well as the job posting

1 Technical:
- Only trivia questions and no coding.
- Ask about C++: How does vector work internally? new vs malloc? smart pointer?
- Ask about networking: TCP vs UDP? Peer vs Client/Server?

1 Behavorial:
- Chatted with the managers.
- Some common questions: Why do you want to work here? What would you do if no one's there to help you? How do you approach on-boarding? Tell me about a time you show leadership, etc.
reviews.Comments:
The experience overall was very enjoyable. The recruiter scheduled both rounds, instead of waiting to pass one round before moving on to another. The managers and engineers were very social, and they made the interview seems more like a chat instead of an interview. 

Though, make sure to "keep you guards up"! I told them I've been playing fifa since FIFA 14, they'd try and ask about things like gamemode and such to see if I'm telling the truth. They also really like if you're able to draw relevant experience that would happen in EA.

interviewDetails.1764088914920: The OA was a generic HackerRank test. I received 3 questions of varying difficulty to do in 90 minutes. It wasn't particularly difficult, but the topics were not concentrated, as I got asked DP questions and other people I know who interviewed got asked a range of DSA, so it's best to brush up on a lot of topics if you have the time.
interviewDetails.1764089275648: Was a casual, informal chat with my recruiter, talking about my background and why I wanted to work at Affirm. Got to ask a lot of questions about their experience working at Affirm, as well as stuff about the culture, the WLB, the teams, and had a good experience overall.
interviewDetails.1764089361294: Not your typical DSA-heavy interview with complex data structures and algorithms, but rather simulated a real-life problem and was very reading-heavy. I liked the interview process a lot more cause it wasn't about memorizing questions beforehand, but rather focusing on the communication aspect of the problem.
interviewDetails.1764089381504: The final coding round was similar to the first, but the behavioral was on the same day, so I had to mentally prep for both. Nothing really note-worthy to talk about as it was the same as the first round basically, but both rounds had follow-up questions, so it's important to pace yourself and not take things too slowly.
interviewDetails.1764133734340: Behavioral round was with a manager (not my manager, but a manager), just talked more in-depth about my resume and my background, what I was looking forward to if I joined as an intern and what I wanted to get out of the internship. Asked why I applied to Affirm and how this role would align with my career growth and opportunities.

reviews.Comments: Don't do bad on behavioral, they care a lot about it and give u a fact sheet on it, make sure to not take it lightly

I think this affected my performance and kept me from being shortlisted among the top candidates, especially since the team is small and has limited openings.

interviewDetails.1753122965900:
I was presented with 2 algorithm questions, masked as Object Oriented Design questions.
1/ Design a library where you can add a book with bookTitle, author, and isbn. If a searchKey is given, I have to return a list of books that matches exactly with the searchKey by bookTitle, author, or isbn. 
2/ Design a deck of cards where there is two method: addCard - add the card to the bottom of the deck and drawsCard - removes a card from the top of the deck.

For both questions I was asked about the runtime and memory complexity of my implementation

reviews.InterviewInformation: The interview was completely behavioural. It was very chill and quite frankly enjoyable. There is one slightly technical question where they asked me to analyze a C program to 1. spot and fix a bug 2. which LINE takes the longest. It did require some relevant knowledge in OS and low-level programming, but it wasn't too difficult.
reviews.Comments: MAKE SURE to ask what the team is and what you will be doing as intern. The team I got it was extremely cool, as it was core to Db2 database. But the role I got was essentially QA. I did a lot of testing and fixing tests. It was a big mistake, and I didn't enjoy it as much (though I managed to wiggle myself onto to the main codebase later on, but still didn't get to do as much)

reviews.InterviewInformation:
Recruiter Screen 
- focus on why palantir and tie your previous experiences to palantirs mission
- if you're not genuinely interested, they'll sniff it out
- be genuine and really know your past experiences, why you liked them, why you chose your previous internships, how did your experiences lead you to palantir

Technical
- LC med
- focus on explaining solution and working with interviewer. Ask lots of questions. All questions have edge cases.
- make sure you get big O correct
- Non optimal may be accepted, they focus more on getting to a working solution

Virtual Onsite
- Decomp: system design, vague broad question, my advice don't study too hard. just know rdbms vs nosql
- Learning: you can't prepare, it's like working on a bug in a new language/framework. use prior knowledge to help you better understand the situation and ask the questions you would ask google


Hiring Manager
- they grill tf out of u. make sure you're consistent with what you've said in previous rounds.
- know why you want to be dev vs delta
- they just want to understand your motivations to put you on a good team
- again, can't really prepare for this round because it's extremely unique and different from regular behaviorals. But just be yourself, think about your answers before speaking, and show genuine interest
reviews.Comments:
Very interesting process and nice engineers. Show growth in your process and take feedback received from previous rounds into future rounds.

10k/month + 2.5k/month housing

interviewDetails.1767605565556:
First round was recruiter screening. I was asked questions like:
1. Tell me about yourself
2. What interests you about working at Persona?
3. Do you have visa sponsorship for this role?
4. Will you be available to work hybrid?

I was also told a little bit about what to expect in the process.
interviewDetails.1767605601687:
I was asked to present two projects to a designer (the team lead, I believe). During the presentation, the hiring manager would ask questions about my experience or how I approached certain problems. They're looking to see what the problem you're trying to solve is, your approach, process, and overall craft and execution.


The hiring manager was kind to give me feedback at the end of my portfolio review round, but only because I'd asked for it.
interviewDetails.1767605642649:
This was a casual conversation, with the same designer from the portfolio review round, and the goal was for them to learn more about how you'd fit into the team. I was asked questions like:
1. What's your greatest strength/weakness?
2. What are you hoping to gain from this role?
3. What attributes do you not like in a manager?

I was also able to ask questions about what it's like working at Persona, as well as the structure of the design team.

interviewDetails.1767722076906:
I only had one technical question asked to me after the behavioral. Since I was a co-op looking for an entry level position, the technical question of the interview was if your laundry machine broke down, how would you fix the laundry machine? I'd say

Id start by clarifying what broken means  whether it wont power on, fill, spin, or drain. Id make sure its safe by unplugging it and shutting off water. Then Id break the machine into subsystems: power, water input, motor/drum, drainage, and control. Id begin with the simplest checks like power, door sensors, and water valves, then move toward more complex issues like motor operation or control logic. Id isolate variables, observe behavior, and use each test to narrow the fault. If the issue was beyond safe repair, Id escalate appropriately.
